item.title: Mega Starmie Has Begun Terrorizing Yet Another Side Of The Pokémon Community
item.content:encoded:
Mega Starmie, the long-legged starfish alien(?) mega-evolved Pokémon that debuted in Pokémon Legends: Z-A has been a surprising breakout star since October. Many fans couldn’t stand the thing’s goofy design, but it’s actually kind of a beast in the game, so folks are coming around on the meme machine. However, after making its horrific anime debut, Mega Starmie has now made its way to another side of the Pokémon community where it has started wreaking havoc: competitive TCG play.

The Mega Starmie ex card launched as part of the Japanese Nihil Zero booster set last week, and in just a few short days, it’s becoming a staple in competitive tournaments overseas. As Wargamer lays out, the card is consistently helping players place in Japanese tournaments thanks in no small part to its Jet Blow attack, which does a whopping 120 damage to the opponent’s active Pokémon as well as 50 damage to one on their bench. As such, Mega Starmie ex puts constant pressure on your opponents in a way that sounds kind of broken.

Some are even using it alongside the Risky Ruins stadium card which damages monsters on the bench for an additional 20 HP, so you can feasibly wipe out some benched cards pretty quickly with the right combo. Mega Starmie itself is pretty bulky, too, with 330 HP, so knock it off the field can take some time, and by then, you might already have taken too much damage.

Mega Starmie’s off-putting design and weirdly human mannerisms give it the air of an absolute gremlin troublemaker, so I guess it makes sense that every time it shows up in a different Pokémon game it’s a menace. The Mega Starmie ex card has three variants, including a secret illustration that makes it look like some kind of kaiju monster stomping over a city. It’s fun to see The Pokémon Company leaning into this thing’s chaos energy.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-mega-starmie-ex-nihil-zero-card-tournaments-2000663530

item.title: Garmin Clears Out Fitness GPS Smartwatch at Its Lowest Price, Vívoactive 5 Now Cheaper Than Apple Watches
item.content:encoded:
Looking to take health and fitness a bit more seriously in 2026? You need a solid smartwatch by your side to keep track of your goals and monitor your health levels better. Garmin makes some of the top options around, and you can upgrade to its highly-rated Vivoactive 5 without paying the full price.

That’s thanks to Amazon, as the retailer has knocked an impressive 35% off its usual $300 price, dropping it down to $195. This offer applies to the stunning Ivory version. Some other colors are discounted too, but the prices may vary. For instance, you can grab the Navy model for $200, while the Orchid version is sitting at $191.

See at Amazon

Comes With Over 30 Workout Apps

This watch flaunts a colorful AMOLED display that’s both bright and spacious. It makes it easy to view your stats in any lighting condition, from bright rooms to dark outdoors. The watch itself is also quite lightweight, so you can comfortably wear it for extended periods.

It’s packed with a wide range of health features. We’re talking body battery monitoring, which helps you see your energy levels throughout the day, and get personal insights into how well you’re resting. There’s a built-in sleep coach that monitors your sleep patterns, and shares tips on improving them over time, plus Heart Rate Variability status for a deeper understanding of your overall wellbeing. You’ll also receive a morning report at the start of your day, as soon as you wake up. These reports include a detailed overview of your recovery, sleep, and daily calendars, which you can use to plan your day accordingly.

Fitness enthusiasts will appreciate the over 30 GPS and indoor sports apps that come built right into the watch. You can use these to record everything from your runs, walking, cycling, and even swimming sessions. Additionally, wheelchair mode tracks pushes instead of steps, and includes push and handcycle activities with preloaded workouts for strength, cardio, HIIT, yoga, and other challenges specific to wheelchair users. The workout benefit and recovery time show how each session affects your body, alongside the time you need to recover. You can even train for marathons using the free adaptive 5K, 10, and half-marathon training plans curated by expert coaches.

When you have the watch connected to your smartphone, you will be able to view all your emails, texts, and alerts right on your wrist. Android users can respond to texts using the on-watch keyboard, as well as view photos shared with you! Other than that, you can manage music and even make contactless payments on the go. Best of all, Vivoactive 5 includes built-in incident detection, which sends your live location automatically to contacts when it notices a fall or crash.

There’s a lot more to like about this watch, especially now that you can pick it up for just $195. You’re saving $105 on an option that makes it easy to hit fitness goals, plus monitor your health better. Several color options are going for less, so you can pick the one that fits your aesthetics the best. Be sure to act fast, as the retailer might push the price back up any time now!

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/garmin-clears-out-fitness-gps-smartwatch-at-its-lowest-price-vivoactive-5-now-cheaper-than-apple-watches-2000662881

item.title: Highguard‘s Small Team Sizes Are A Problem
item.content:encoded:
Highguard is out now after a really weird period of time in which it seemed like everyone had an opinion on a game that we’d only seen two minutes of via a Game Awards finale trailer. Anyway, it’s finally here, and I’ve played about six hours of the new free-to-play FPS so far. While I’m not an expert, I have put enough time in solo and with friends to come to one conclusion: 3 players versus 3 players is a problem.

How a match in Highguard works is that two teams of three spend a bit of time setting up defenses at a base, then everyone rushes out into a big map to find loot, and eventually they all race to a large sword that forms somewhere and which can be used by one team to break into the other’s big base. Then a raid happens, with the attacking team trying to blow up key locations like in a match of Counter-Strike with limited respawns, while the defenders try to take them out and stop the assault. Eventually, one team will win, and the other will lose. These matches can be tense and come down to one awesome play by one player. And this is a problem in a 3v3 format.

I think a key aspect of online competitive multiplayer games that doesn’t get talked about much is that you need enough players to let people “blame” someone else.

Battlefield 6, for example, is really good at providing you and your friends plenty of other people you can blame for losses or slow victories. And even Call of Duty, which has smaller lobbies, still has more than 3v3 in most modes, which lets less skilled players feel less pressure to perform perfectly. “It’s okay, there are a few other people. I’m not ruining the match!” And as someone who is good at some shooters and bad at others, being able to blame others or not feel like I’m the sole reason we lost is very helpful.

Highguard’s 3v3 format and focus on tactical teamwork means there’s nowhere for people who are learning or less-skilled players to hide. I had a match in which a teammate I’d been randomly matched with seemed to be still getting the hang of the game, which makes sense as it just launched, but they failed in some team fights and screwed up a key 1v1 battle, and it led to us losing. The other rando I was with wasn’t kind on the mic. Will that less-skilled player want to come back?

3v3 also just feels like too few people for Highguard’s massive maps. The moment one person splits off, they are likely to run into two or three enemy players if they push too far, and that’s a fight they’ll likely lose. With 4v4 or 5v5, people could split up but still have at least a partner to help. It could make base defense more exciting as you could more evenly split yourselves between the bombs and make rotating less necessary, which would help when playing with no-mic randos.

I’m not suggesting that developer Wildlight can just go in, flip a switch and instantly turn Highguard into a 4v4 or 5v5 game. But, if the team is looking for a way to bring in more players and make it easier for casual shooter fans to enjoy what it offers, I think upping the playercount in a “casual” mode that also contains a few other tweaks could go a long way toward helping Highguard stick around and even grow.



https://kotaku.com/highguards-small-team-sizes-are-a-problem-2000663511
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Valve Fails To Get $900m Class Action Lawsuit Over Pricing Thrown Out
item.content:encoded:
Valve’s attempt to have courts dismiss a legal action brought against it for allegations of overcharging and anti-competitive practices has failed, as reported by the BBC. A judge’s ruling is allowing the case brought by lawyer Vicki Shotbolt to go ahead on behalf of 14 million Steam users in the UK.

First filed in 2024, Shotbolt’s claim (with its own fancy website) is an attempt to prove that Valve’s policies on Steam violate UK laws on “anti-competitive prices” and “unfair trading conditions that prevent or hinder others from competing with them.” The argument concerns Valve’s demand that games sold on Steam not be made available at a permanently lower price on rival stores, and that once you buy a game on Steam, the only way you can buy further content for that game—be it DLC, expansion packs or cosmetics—is also via Steam. This, Shotbolt claims, allows Valve to “hold a dominant position in the PC gaming market” and “that it may have used this position in ways that violate UK competition law.”

Class action lawsuits are not a commonplace event in the UK, where the mass litigation is known as a “collective action claim,” and works on an “opt-out” basis. Basically, Shotbolt and her law firm are going to sue Valve on behalf of British Steam users unless they specifically say they don’t want in. That’s how it’s able to claim to be suing on behalf of 14 million people.

Valve, obviously, objects to the claims, and filed to have the case thrown out. A ruling filed January 26 by the Competition Appeal Tribunal says that Valve opposed on the basis that the “PCR” (the shorthand for Shotbolt’s group) “had not put forward an adequate methodology” before venturing all manner of peculiarly specific fiddly details about “determining the effect of the alleged PPOs [Platform Parity Obligations]” and that the “class definition was inadequate” and so on. The latter was seemingly based on lots of kids using Steam, and how they couldn’t opt in or out of the action. It all seemed to amount to “They didn’t cross their Ts sufficiently,” and the tribunal was having none of that.

Shotbolt’s team promised to double-check their punctuation, and that seemed to be enough to have Valve’s concerns overturned. “The PCR proposed revisions to the proposed class definition which substantially diminished the concerns raised by Valve,” says the ruling, which appears to mean they rejigged things to ensure it was just representing over 13s…I think? “In light of that development,” says the ruling, “the Tribunal rejected Valve’s challenge in this respect.”

All of that basically amounts to “Yup, this action can go ahead,” which will mightily annoy Valve. Those who don’t want to be included in the entire PC gaming population of Britain will have the option to opt out pretty soon, given the site’s FAQ stated it was waiting for this very certification before offering the option. Given 99.9 percent of Steam users will never even know this action is taking place, that sounds impressively farcical.

Should the PCR win, it’ll mean everyone in the UK is entitled to some money back, which will likely be fairly meaningless amounts to all involved except for Valve. The claim is looking for £656 million, which at the time of writing is $904 million. Given that when we first covered this story in 2024 that figure converted to $838 million, Valve will likely hope for a quick resolution before Trump manages to tank the dollar even further.



https://kotaku.com/valve-class-action-lawsuit-steam-uk-ruling-2000663481
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Anker’s 26,250mAh Power Bank Hits Its First Low of the Year as This 300W Max 3-Port Charger Starts Selling Out Fast
item.content:encoded:
The Anker Prime Power Bank is a 26,250 mAh portable power bank with three ports, a compact Phantom Gray housing, and compatibility with laptops, tablets, and phones. The Anker Prime Power Bank allows you to charge up to 300W through two USB-C ports and one USB-A port, so a notebook, phone, and additional items, such as headphones or earbuds, can charge at the same time without taking turns. It’s small enough to fit into backpacks and carry-on luggage and has a TSA-approved battery size, so you can generally fly with it. There is also a smart display screen on the front of the unit that shows charging information.

You can find the Anker Prime Power Bank on Amazon today for $171, down from its original $230, which represents a savings of $59 and 26% off the original retail price.

See at Amazon

A hefty power bank with plenty of charging power

The charging configuration on the Anker Prime Power Bank is optimized for rapid charging of larger items while supporting smaller items. One USB-C port delivers up to 140W with a compatible 5A cable for rapid laptop recharging, and the other two USB-C and USB-A ports recharge your phone, earbuds, or other accessories simultaneously. With a maximum of 300W, you can use the bank as a central charging station rather than just to recharge your phone.

The Anker Prime Power Bank was also optimized to charge quickly, allowing the unit to spend more time available for use rather than idling due to discharge. The dual USB-C ports will accept up to 250W of combined input and allow the bank to recharge to approximately 50% in around 13 minutes and fully recharge in approximately 1 hour if you have the correct chargers.

In addition to displaying how much capacity remains in the bank and the current amount of power it is supplying, a smart display will show the status of each device currently charging via a simple visual display, eliminating the need to guess whether a device is charging. When paired with Anker’s app, you can view charging activity in even greater detail and adjust your usage preferences for how you want power used.

The flexibility of the overall design allows users to place the Anker Prime Power Bank wherever they want to recharge their devices, including desks, bags, hotel nightstands, and many other locations. The bank’s compact frame is light enough for daily carrying but feels sturdy and substantial when placed next to a laptop with several cables plugged into it. In the box, you will receive the Anker Prime Power Bank, a 3.3-foot-long 240W USB-C to USB-C cable, a travel pouch, a welcome guide, and a 24-month limited hardware warranty. With the entire package bundled at $171 instead of the usual $230, the Anker Prime Power Bank is an affordable source of portable power in one small unit.

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/ankers-26250mah-power-bank-hits-its-first-low-of-the-year-as-this-300w-max-3-port-charger-starts-selling-out-fast-2000663253

item.title: Kotaku Is Hiring A Staff Reporter
item.content:encoded:
Kotaku is seeking an experienced writer and reporter to help drive our coverage of the biggest stories in gaming, focusing on everything from companies and communities to hit releases and the under-covered trends shaping the culture. 

This role will regularly cover breaking news, contribute original reporting, and work on big features about the world of video games on a weekly basis. You’ll develop and source specific news beats while also contributing to the rest of the site’s gaming coverage. We want someone who’s as hungry to break the news of the next major blockbuster delay as they are to dig into the fascinating things players are doing in games. 

You are a fit for this role if:

  • You can write and edit sharp, accessible stories about gaming’s business side and its cultural footprint, from major acquisitions to niche role-play communities
  • You have a punchy writing voice and are familiar with Kotaku’s general tone and subject areas
  • You can quickly turn around timely news hits and short analysis pieces that explain why a story matters and what the larger implications of it are
  • You’re eager to collaborate with other editors and writers to ensure our coverage is fast, fair, and full of voice
  • You have a keen news sense and can identify stories that will resonate with our audience, especially the ones that no one else is paying attention to
  • You can exercise strong editorial judgment and have a strong grasp of media law and journalistic best practices
  • You bring sharp angles and fresh framing to the day’s headlines, with a sense of humor and wit that matches Kotaku’s style
  • You are familiar with the major companies, franchises, and trends in gaming
  • You have the editorial sensibility to know when a story needs speed, when it needs depth, and when it needs both
  • You have experience developing sources and breaking stories that will surprise, inform, and entertain our readers

This is a position covered under the collective bargaining agreement with the WGA-E. The salary range for this position is $64,000 – $82,000.

Kotaku’s US office is located in NYC. We are open to both NYC-based and remote candidates who live within the US.

**To apply, please email a resume, short cover letter, and 3-5 clips to [email protected]**



https://kotaku.com/kotaku-is-hiring-a-staff-reporter-2000663475
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Kotaku Is Hiring A Nights And Weekends Editor
item.content:encoded:
Kotaku is seeking an experienced, self-directed writer to help drive our coverage of the most interesting stories in gaming, focusing on everything from companies and communities to hit releases and the latest cultural trends. 

The Nights and Weekends Editor will work three weekday evenings (3pm – 11pm ET) and Saturday and Sunday (9am – 5pm ET). During the week, you’ll do a mix of writing your own stories and editing stories from staff and freelancers. On the weekends, you’ll focus on fast, smart news writing, covering breaking news while also surfacing interesting stories that are going under the radar. 

You are a fit for this role if:

  • You consistently file clean copy and have experience editing others
  • You have a keen news sense and can identify stories our readers care about, especially ones that aren’t coming from an industry press release 
  • You have a punchy writing voice and are familiar with Kotaku’s general tone and coverage areas
  • You can self-direct, self-publish, and exercise strong editorial judgment while working solo during off-hours 
  • You bring sharp angles and fresh framing to the day’s headlines, with a sense of humor, wit, and expertise that matches Kotaku’s style
  • You are familiar with the major companies, franchises, debates, and trends in gaming
  • You have a good grasp of media law and journalistic best practices
  • You have the editorial sensibility to know when a story needs speed, when it needs depth, and when it needs both

This is a position covered under the collective bargaining agreement with the WGA-E. The salary range for this position is $70,000 – $82,000.

Kotaku’s US office is located in NYC. We are open to both NYC-based and remote candidates who live within the US. 

**To apply, please email a resume, short cover letter, and 3-5 clips to [email protected]**



https://kotaku.com/kotaku-is-hiring-a-nights-and-weekends-editor-2000663478
